quoteFirst: The man is a marvel—sixty-nine years old, a life of hardship, and as sturdy as a lion. Yet of the past night alone his hours had been:
quoteTime: four to six in the afternoon
quoteLast: on deck; eight to twelve on deck; and four to eight in the morning on deck. In a few minutes he would be relieved, but at midday he would again be on deck.
title: The Mutiny of the Elsinore
author: London, Jack, 1876-1916

quoteFirst: They were heading toward their Captain's cottage. This was not only astonishing, but it was strictly against the rules, as all interviews with the Captain, while on shore, were limited to the hours from
quoteLast: It was now 7.30. Black Pedro leaped to his feet in surprise. The men formed a line in front of the cottage--thirty-four of them--while old Aaron tottered forward.
title: The Voyage of the Hoppergrass
author: Pearson, Edmund Lester, 1880-1937

quoteFirst:
They bent their heads over them for a time.

“That’s it. At
quoteLast:
by yours. Seven to by mine.”

It was the cuirassier who remained by the side of General D’Hubert, keeping his one eye fixed immovably on the white face of the watch he held in the palm of his hand.
title: A Set of Six
author: Conrad, Joseph, 1857-1924

quoteFirst: Roughly, very roughly, speaking, our destroyers enjoyed three phases of "prompt decisive action"--the first, a period of daylight attacks (from
quoteLast: ) such as the one I have just described, while the battle was young and the light fairly good on the afternoon of May 31; the second, towards dark, when the light had lessened and the enemy were more uneasy, and, I think, in more scattered formation; the third, when darkness had fallen, and the destroyers had been strung out astern with orders to help the enemy home, which they did all night as opportunity offered.
title: Sea Warfare
author: Kipling, Rudyard, 1865-1936

quoteFirst: The man is a marvel—sixty-nine years old, a life of hardship, and as sturdy as a lion. Yet of the past night alone his hours had been:

author: London, Jack, 1876-1916

quoteFirst: A. M., 8 A. M. to 12 M.,
quoteLast: , and 8 to 12 P. M., and so on in uninterrupted succession. This was rather hard work for one who was fond of comfort and late breakfasts, but I speedily learned not to lose any time in going to sleep, and undressing appeared a useless indulgence. This was not the worst of it.
title: Reminiscences of Confederate Service, 1861-1865
author: Dawson, Francis Warrington, 1840-1889

quoteFirst: Then came a pleasant diversion; how pleasant only those can know who for many months have been denied all the intercourse with their kind outside of the little population of the ship. Pepe being at the masthead from
quoteLast: yelled “Sail ho.” This was the first cry of that kind that the crew had heard since leaving Norfolk Island, and be sure they were proportionately excited.
title:
A Bounty Boy
Being Some Adventures of a Christian Barbarian on an Unpremeditated Trip Round the World
author: Bullen, Frank Thomas, 1857-1915

quoteFirst: The old lady consented to let me live in the cottage until a permanent tenant should appear, and she was willing to take care of me for a certain payment per week. I accepted her terms on condition that she allow me to work off a certain part of the agreed amount by sawing kindling-wood from ten to twelve in the morning and from
quoteTime: four to six in the afternoon
quoteLast: . My suggestion made her thoughtful, and she finally confessed her fear that my exercises before meals might give me such an appetite that I should eat her out of house and home. We agreed to try the scheme for a week, and we were both satisfied with the result.
title: From Immigrant to Inventor
author: Pupin, Michael, 1858-1935

quoteFirst: HARRODS ROYAL RED BAND
title: Harrods for Everything
author: Harrods Ltd.

quoteFirst: The next thing to be done was the arrangement of the ship's company into messes, "four to a mess," after which the custom was to "give every messe a quarter Can of beere and a bisket of bread to stay their stomacks till the kettle be boiled." In the first dog-watch, from
quoteLast: , all hands went to prayers about the main-mast, and from their devotions to supper. At 6 P.M. the company met again to sing a psalm, and say their prayers, before the setting of the night watch; this psalm singing being the prototype of the modern sea-concert, or singsong. At 8 P.M. the first night watch began, lasting until midnight, during which four hours half the ship's company were free to sleep.
title: On the Spanish Main; Or, Some English forays on the Isthmus of Darien
author: Masefield, John, 1878-1967

quoteFirst: The day was, indeed, divided into six watches of four hours each, but the last watch of each working day, viz. that from 4 to 8 p.m., was subdivided into two "dog" watches of two hours each. Nearly all the pleasant memories of fo'c'sle life cluster around the second of these. From
title:
The Men of the Merchant Service
Being the polity of the mercantile marine for 'longshore readers
author: Bullen, Frank Thomas, 1857-1915
